stories.title: The European Wanderer
stories.intended_reader: Those who sailed Splendour during her European and transatlantic years
stories.core_insight: Splendour specialized in European cruising and became beloved for Mediterranean and transatlantic itineraries
stories.markdown:
**Splendour of the Seas launched in April 1996 as the sixth and final Vision-class ship.**

Where her Vision-class sisters ([Grandeur](/ships/rcl/grandeur-of-the-seas.html), [Rhapsody](/ships/rcl/rhapsody-of-the-seas.html), [Vision](/ships/rcl/vision-of-the-seas.html), [Enchantment](/ships/rcl/enchantment-of-the-seas.html)) sailed Caribbean and Alaska routes, Splendour carved a different identity: European specialist, Mediterranean wanderer, transatlantic crossings.

**The facts:**
- Entered service: April 1996
- Gross tonnage: 69,130 GT
- Capacity: 1,804 passengers (double occupancy)
- Length: 867 feet
- Built by: Chantiers de l'Atlantique, France
- Primary routes: Mediterranean (summer), transatlantic repositioning (spring/fall), occasional Caribbean (winter)
- Notable features: Seven-story atrium, Viking Crown Lounge, extensive glass walls for European sightseeing
- Retired from Royal Caribbean: 2016 (sold to TUI Cruises, became Marella Discovery, still sailing as of 2025)

**What made Splendour beloved:**

Splendour spent most of her Royal Caribbean career sailing Europe: Barcelona to Rome, Greek Islands, Adriatic ports, Western Mediterranean loops. Summer seasons in the Med, repositioning transatlantic crossings in spring and fall, occasional Caribbean winters.

European cruisers developed loyalty to Splendour specifically. She wasn't the newest or largest ship, but she was *right-sized* for European ports—small enough to dock in Santorini, Dubrovnik, and Venice (ports that mega-ships couldn't access), big enough to offer Royal Caribbean's signature service and entertainment.

stories.title: What Splendour Passengers Valued
stories.intended_reader: Splendour loyalists who preferred her European itineraries
stories.core_insight: Splendour proved that mid-sized ships offered advantages mega-ships couldn't match for European cruising
stories.markdown:
**Common praise from Splendour passengers (documented in reviews and forums):**

"She could dock in ports [Oasis class](/ships/rcl/oasis-of-the-seas.html) couldn't reach. That alone made her invaluable for Mediterranean cruising."

"Right-sized for Europe. Not too big to feel impersonal, not too small to lack amenities."

"The transatlantic crossings were bucket-list experiences. Seven days at sea, formal nights, lectures, no port distractions."

"Glass walls everywhere—perfect for scenic cruising. Norwegian fjords, Greek coastlines, you didn't want to miss the views."

"When Royal Caribbean sold her in 2016, European cruisers lost a gem. The newer ships are impressive, but they can't dock where Splendour could."

**Documented achievements:**
- Sailed Mediterranean itineraries for over 15 consecutive summers
- Completed dozens of transatlantic crossings, becoming a favorite for passengers who preferred sea days over port-hopping
- Accessed smaller European ports that larger ships (Voyager, Oasis class) couldn't reach
- Maintained high satisfaction scores despite being one of the older Vision-class ships

**Life after Royal Caribbean:**

In 2016, Royal Caribbean sold Splendour to TUI Cruises (UK market). She was refurbished, renamed Marella Discovery, and continues sailing Mediterranean and European itineraries as of 2025.

Unlike many retired ships that were scrapped, Splendour received a second career. She's still out there—different name, different line, same European waters she always loved.

**The legacy:**

Splendour proved that mid-sized ships (69,000 GT) could thrive in European markets where mega-ships struggled. Her success influenced Royal Caribbean's later decisions to deploy smaller ships ([Brilliance](/ships/rcl/brilliance-of-the-seas.html), [Serenade](/ships/rcl/serenade-of-the-seas.html)) to Europe instead of forcing mega-ships into ports they couldn't access.

See other Vision-class ships: [Grandeur](/ships/rcl/grandeur-of-the-seas.html), [Rhapsody](/ships/rcl/rhapsody-of-the-seas.html), [Vision](/ships/rcl/vision-of-the-seas.html), [Enchantment](/ships/rcl/enchantment-of-the-seas.html).

stories.title: My First Transatlantic: Seven Days at Sea
stories.intended_reader: Travelers considering repositioning cruises or who enjoy sea days
stories.core_insight: Splendour's transatlantic crossings offered a unique cruise experience focused on shipboard life rather than ports
stories.markdown:
**I booked Splendour's spring repositioning cruise from Barcelona to Fort Lauderdale. Seven consecutive sea days. Best cruise decision I ever made.**

Most cruisers want ports. They want beach days, shore excursions, port shopping. They treat the ship as transportation between destinations.

Transatlantic crossings flip that entirely. The ship IS the destination. No ports. No excursions. Just you, the ocean, and seven days of uninterrupted shipboard life.

**What made Splendour's transatlantic special:**

The daily routine became meditative. Wake up. Coffee on the balcony, watching the Atlantic. Breakfast at your own pace—no rush to disembark. Morning enrichment lectures: navigation, maritime history, destination briefings. Afternoon by the pool or in the library. Cocktails at Viking Crown Lounge as the sun set. Formal dinners that felt earned.

Splendour was right-sized for transatlantic. Small enough to feel like a community—you recognized faces, made friends, had dinner companions. Large enough to never feel trapped—multiple bars, lounges, activities, deck space.

**The people:**

Transatlantic cruisers are different. They're not chasing beaches or shopping. They're often retired, experienced travelers, people who value the journey over destinations. Conversations were deeper. Connections felt more genuine.

I met a couple from London on day two. By day five, we were sharing life stories over wine. We've stayed in touch for years.

**The practical truth:**

Seven sea days sounds long. It isn't. The days flew by. I read four books. I attended every lecture. I tried every bar. I watched dolphins from the bow. I saw bioluminescence in the ship's wake at midnight.

When we docked in Fort Lauderdale, I didn't want to leave. The ocean had become home.

Splendour no longer sails for Royal Caribbean, but repositioning cruises still exist on other ships. If you've never done a transatlantic: do it. It's cruising in its purest form.

See our [repositioning cruise guide](/planning.html) for current options.

stories.title: Venice to Barcelona: Mediterranean Magic
stories.core_insight: Splendour's size allowed access to intimate Mediterranean ports that larger ships couldn't reach
stories.markdown:
**Our honeymoon cruise on Splendour started in Venice. We watched St. Mark's Square disappear as we sailed through the lagoon. Nothing has topped that moment.**

We chose Splendour specifically because she could dock in Venice. The mega-ships anchored in industrial ports, requiring water taxis into the city. Splendour sailed directly into the Venice cruise terminal—walk off the ship, walk into history.

That pattern repeated throughout the cruise.

**The ports:**

Dubrovnik: Docked at the cruise port, walked along the old city walls within minutes. No tender boats, no shuttles, no wasted time.

Santorini: This port required a tender, but Splendour's smaller size meant shorter queues and more flexibility. We had morning coffee watching the caldera, then spent the entire day exploring Oia.

Barcelona: Docked at the main terminal, walked to Las Ramblas. The city felt accessible, not distant.

**Why size mattered:**

Oasis-class ships (225,000 GT) carry 6,000+ passengers. They overwhelm small ports. They anchor offshore and tender thousands of people in waves. They create crowds that spoil the experience.

Splendour (69,000 GT) carried 1,800 passengers. We never felt like an invasion force. Ports felt welcoming, not overwhelmed. Local restaurants could accommodate us. Cobblestone streets weren't packed.

**The romance factor:**

Every evening, we'd watch the sunset from Viking Crown Lounge—360-degree glass walls, the Mediterranean turning gold and pink, no noise except quiet conversation and clinking glasses.

Formal nights in the dining room felt elegant, not rushed. Our server remembered our wine preference by night two. The maitre d' sent champagne to our table when he learned we were honeymooners.

Smaller ship, bigger moments.

Splendour is gone from Royal Caribbean, but [Brilliance](/ships/rcl/brilliance-of-the-seas.html) and [Serenade](/ships/rcl/serenade-of-the-seas.html) still offer similar Mediterranean experiences on right-sized ships.

See our [Mediterranean cruise guide](/ports.html) for current itinerary options.

stories.title: The Glass Walls That Defined a Class
stories.intended_reader: Ship enthusiasts interested in Vision Class design history
stories.core_insight: Vision Class ships, including Splendour, pioneered glass-wall design that influenced all future Royal Caribbean ships
stories.markdown:
**Vision Class ships weren't just ships. They were architectural statements. Splendour exemplified everything the class represented.**

When Royal Caribbean launched Legend of the Seas in 1995 (the first Vision-class ship), the industry noticed something different: glass everywhere. Floor-to-ceiling windows in the dining room. Glass elevators in the atrium. The Viking Crown Lounge wrapped entirely in glass. Even the health center had ocean views.

Splendour, launched in 1996, perfected the concept.

**Why glass mattered:**

Before Vision Class, cruise ships were designed like floating hotels—interior-focused, minimal windows, artificial lighting. You could forget you were at sea.

Vision Class made the ocean inescapable. Every meal, every walk, every elevator ride reminded you that you were sailing across water. The glass walls transformed cruising from "traveling on a ship" to "experiencing the ocean."

**Splendour's design signatures:**

The seven-story Centrum atrium: glass elevators ascending through the heart of the ship, natural light flooding every level.

Viking Crown Lounge: perched at the top, wrapped in glass, 360-degree views that made every sunset a private show.

Windjammer Café: wall-to-wall windows, breakfast with Mediterranean coastlines or Atlantic horizons as backdrop.

Even the corridors had windows at each end—you could always orient yourself by looking at the ocean.

**The legacy:**

Vision Class proved that passengers wanted connection to the sea, not isolation from it. Every Royal Caribbean ship since has incorporated glass design elements: the AquaTheater on Oasis Class, the observation pods on Quantum Class, the glass-bottom Overlook Bar on Icon Class.

Splendour and her sisters didn't just carry passengers—they changed how cruise ships were designed.

Explore Vision-class ships still sailing: [Grandeur](/ships/rcl/grandeur-of-the-seas.html), [Rhapsody](/ships/rcl/rhapsody-of-the-seas.html), [Vision](/ships/rcl/vision-of-the-seas.html), [Enchantment](/ships/rcl/enchantment-of-the-seas.html).

stories.title: Accessible Cruising on Splendour: What Worked
stories.intended_reader: Travelers with mobility needs researching historical accessibility standards
stories.core_insight: Splendour's compact layout made wheelchair navigation easier than on larger, more sprawling ships
stories.markdown:
**My father used a wheelchair. We cruised Splendour three times before she was sold. Here's what worked—and what didn't.**

**What worked:**

Compact layout. Splendour was small enough that Dad could navigate independently. Cabin to dining room: five minutes. Cabin to pool: three minutes. Everything was reachable without exhaustion.

Elevators. Vision-class glass elevators were positioned centrally and rarely overcrowded. Dad never waited more than two minutes. On larger ships, elevator waits could hit ten minutes during peak times.

Accessible cabin design. The accessible cabin had wide doorways, roll-in shower, grab bars, lowered closet rods. Not perfect, but functional. The balcony was large enough for the wheelchair.

Crew attitude. The staff learned Dad's routine and anticipated needs. Our cabin steward knew when to have the room ready. The dining staff had his table prepared. Small ship meant personal recognition.

**What didn't work:**

Tender ports. Santorini, Montenegro, some Greek islands required tender boats. Getting Dad's wheelchair onto tenders was challenging. We sometimes skipped tender ports entirely.

Pool access. No lift into the main pool. The Solarium was more accessible but still required transfers. Dad mostly watched from poolside.

Some public areas. A few bars and lounges had steps without ramps. The casino had tight spacing. The library had narrow aisles.

**The honest assessment:**

Splendour wasn't perfect for wheelchair users, but her size made her more manageable than mega-ships. The crew's attentiveness compensated for design limitations. Dad felt welcome and cared for—that mattered more than perfect accessibility.

For wheelchair users considering current ships: [Radiance Class](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html) offers similar compact layouts with updated accessibility features. Mega-ships have more accessible amenities but require much more navigation.

See our [accessible cruise guide](/accessibility.html) for current recommendations.

stories.title: Norwegian Fjords: Why Splendour Was Built for This
stories.core_insight: Splendour's glass-wall design and smaller size made her ideal for scenic cruising through narrow waterways
stories.markdown:
**Some ships are built for activities. Splendour was built for views. The Norwegian fjords proved it.**

We sailed Splendour's fjord itinerary three consecutive summers. Same ship, same route, never got old. The glass walls made the experience.

**Why Splendour excelled:**

The fjords are narrow. Waterfalls cascade feet from the ship. Cliffs rise thousands of feet on both sides. You don't want to be inside—you want to SEE.

Splendour's glass everywhere meant you could watch the scenery from almost any public space. Breakfast in the Windjammer with Geirangerfjord sliding past the windows. Lunch on the pool deck with waterfalls misting the air. Dinner in the main dining room as the sun set over distant peaks.

**The navigation moments:**

Norwegian fjord cruising includes passages that feel impossibly tight. The captain would announce when we were approaching scenic highlights. Everyone would rush to the deck, cameras ready.

Splendour's smaller size meant she could navigate passages that mega-ships couldn't attempt. We visited villages accessible only by sea, docked at piers that couldn't handle larger vessels.

**The family experience:**

My kids were 10 and 14. They'd grown up on Caribbean cruises, focused on pools and activities. Norway changed their perspective.

Watching a waterfall from feet away. Seeing glaciers calve. Spotting seals and seabirds. The scenery entertained them more than any onboard activity could.

By the third cruise, they requested Norway specifically. "It's not about the ship, Mom," my daughter said. "It's about what's outside the ship."

That's what Splendour understood. The ship wasn't the destination—it was the window to the destination.

Splendour no longer sails, but other ships offer Norwegian fjord itineraries. Look for smaller ships with significant deck space and glass walls. The views matter more than the waterslides.

See our [Norwegian fjord guide](/ports.html) for current cruise options.

stories.title: A Veteran's Mediterranean Memories
stories.core_insight: Splendour's European itineraries allowed veterans to revisit significant historical sites in comfort
stories.markdown:
**I served in the Navy for 30 years. I saw the Mediterranean from warships. Sailing it on Splendour was healing.**

My wife convinced me to try cruising after retirement. I was skeptical—crowds, confined spaces, forced fun didn't appeal. She suggested Splendour's Mediterranean itinerary because she knew the ports.

She also knew I needed to see those places differently.

**The revisitation:**

Naples: I'd pulled into Naples harbor dozens of times on destroyers. Always on duty, always focused on operations, never actually saw the city. On Splendour, we toured Pompeii. My wife held my hand as I stood in the ruins, finally experiencing what I'd sailed past for decades.

Dubrovnik: I'd tracked naval movements along the Adriatic during the Yugoslav wars. Now I walked the old city walls with my grandchildren, explaining history they were too young to understand but would remember.

Barcelona: I'd anchored offshore for NATO exercises. This time I tasted paella, wandered Gaudí's architecture, sat in quiet squares.

**Why Splendour worked:**

Smaller ship meant less chaos. I could find quiet spaces when I needed them. The library. The aft deck at dawn. The Viking Crown Lounge before breakfast.

The crew was professional but not intrusive. They reminded me of good sailors—doing their jobs well, anticipating needs, not making a production of it.

The pace was gentle. We could explore ports or stay aboard. No pressure. No schedules beyond dinner time.

**The peace:**

On the last night, I stood on the aft deck watching our wake disappear into the darkness. I'd spent 30 years watching wakes from warships—always heading somewhere, always on mission.

This time, I was just... sailing. No mission. No threat board. No watch rotation. Just the Mediterranean night and the sound of the sea.

My wife found me there. "You okay?" she asked.

"Better than okay," I said. "I finally got to enjoy it."

Splendour gave me that. I'll always be grateful.

For fellow veterans considering Mediterranean cruises: smaller ships like [Brilliance](/ships/rcl/brilliance-of-the-seas.html) or [Serenade](/ships/rcl/serenade-of-the-seas.html) still offer similar European itineraries.

See our [veteran travel resources](/planning.html) and [Mediterranean cruise guide](/ports.html).

stories.title: The Final Sailing: When Splendour Left Royal Caribbean
stories.intended_reader: Those who sailed Splendour's final Royal Caribbean sailing in 2016
stories.core_insight: Splendour's final sailing brought together passengers who had formed lasting connections with the ship
stories.markdown:
**I sailed Splendour's final Royal Caribbean cruise in April 2016. It was a goodbye to more than just a ship.**

My husband and I had sailed Splendour eight times. Mediterranean loops, transatlantic crossings, even a Caribbean winter sailing when she repositioned. She became "our" ship—the one we requested, the one we returned to.

Robert passed in 2014. I sailed the final cruise alone, carrying his memory.

**The farewell atmosphere:**

The ship was full of Splendour loyalists. People who'd sailed her dozens of times. Crew members who'd been aboard for years. Everyone knew this was the end.

The captain made special announcements throughout the cruise, sharing Splendour's history and achievements. The crew seemed to move a little slower, savor moments a little longer. Even the formal nights felt more meaningful—people dressed up like they were honoring the ship, not just following dress codes.

**The connections:**

I met a couple from Germany who'd sailed Splendour 23 times. A British widow, like me, whose late husband had proposed in Viking Crown Lounge. A family from Australia who'd chosen Splendour for every European vacation for 15 years.

We exchanged stories over wine. Compared favorite ports. Shared memories of crew members long since transferred. Laughed about adventures. Cried about losses.

By the last night, strangers had become family.

**The final departure:**

In Barcelona, as passengers disembarked for the last time, crew members lined the gangway. Many had tears in their eyes. They weren't just saying goodbye to passengers—they were saying goodbye to their shipboard home.

I touched the railing one last time. "Thank you," I whispered. "For everything."

Splendour sailed to TUI shortly after, becoming Marella Discovery. She's still out there, still sailing European waters. Different name, different crew, but the glass walls and Viking Crown Lounge remain.

Sometimes I imagine Robert there still, watching the sunset from our favorite spot.

For those who sailed Splendour: she's not forgotten. This page exists to remember.

stories.title: Life After Royal Caribbean: Splendour as Marella Discovery
stories.intended_reader: Travelers curious about where Splendour is now
stories.core_insight: Splendour continues sailing as Marella Discovery, preserving much of her original character
stories.markdown:
**Splendour of the Seas didn't disappear. She just changed names.**

In 2016, Royal Caribbean sold Splendour to TUI Cruises, the British leisure travel company. The ship was refurbished, repainted, and renamed Marella Discovery. She entered service for TUI's Marella Cruises brand.

**What changed:**

Exterior colors: Royal Caribbean's distinctive blue-white scheme became Marella's blue-silver livery.

Branding: Crown and Anchor logos replaced with Marella branding. Viking Crown Lounge renamed but structurally identical.

Itineraries: Shifted to British-market Mediterranean and Caribbean cruises, departing from UK ports.

Onboard experience: All-inclusive pricing (drinks, tips included). British entertainment and dining preferences.

**What stayed:**

The glass walls. The seven-story atrium. The general layout and flow. The intimate, manageable size.

Passengers who sailed both versions report that Marella Discovery "feels" like Splendour. The bones are the same. The views are the same. The experience of sailing a mid-sized, glass-wrapped ship through European waters—that's unchanged.

**Where she sails now:**

As of 2025, Marella Discovery primarily sails Mediterranean and Caribbean itineraries from UK ports. She occasionally does repositioning cruises and longer voyages.

**For former Splendour passengers:**

If you want to sail "Splendour" again, Marella Discovery offers that opportunity. The ship has been updated but not transformed. Walking the decks, watching sunset from the observation lounge, dining in the main restaurant—these experiences remain available.

She's 30 years old now but still sailing. Still glass-wrapped. Still carrying passengers through European waters.

Some ships are scrapped when they retire from major cruise lines. Splendour got a second life. She deserved it.

**For current cruising on Vision-class ships:**

[Grandeur of the Seas](/ships/rcl/grandeur-of-the-seas.html), [Rhapsody of the Seas](/ships/rcl/rhapsody-of-the-seas.html), [Vision of the Seas](/ships/rcl/vision-of-the-seas.html), and [Enchantment of the Seas](/ships/rcl/enchantment-of-the-seas.html) still sail for Royal Caribbean, offering similar intimate, glass-walled experiences.
